LearningResources.Name: How to Add Google Analytics Tracking to a Website

ReviewJobs.Name: Collects analytics using analytics libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


Analytic events are typically used in applications to gather information about how users interact with the software, such as clicks on buttons, page views, or form submissions. By tracking these events, developers can gain insights into user behavior and make informed decisions about how to improve the application.


Skills


Google analytics

  • Sets up the Google Analytics tracking code in the application.
  • Creates code to track a GA event.
  • Uses Google Tag Assistant to verify that the tracking code is working correctly.
  • Uses Google Analytics Debug mode to troubleshoot issues.


Meta Pixel

  • Sets up the Meta Pixel code in the application.
  • Creates code to track an event.
  • Uses Meta Events Manager.


Mixpanel

  • Installs and configures the Mixpanel SDK in an application.
  • Creates code to track an event.
  • Uses the Mixpanel dashboard.


Knowledge


Google analytics

  • What is the process for adding the Google Analytics tracking code to a web application?
  • How to set up Google Analytics goals and conversions?
  • How to use Google Tag Manager to track events?


Meta Pixel

  • What are the different types of events that can be tracked using Meta Pixel?
  • How to set up conversion tracking with Meta Pixel?
  • How to configure custom variables in Meta Pixel?


Mixpanel

  • How is the Mixpanel SDK installed and configured in an application?
  • How to define and track custom events?
  • What is Mixpanel's Data Export API and how can it be used?
  • How to access and analyze data using Mixpanel's web interface?

LearningResources.Name: Enriched Web API Documentation using Swagger/OpenAPI
Generate interactive API documentation from OpenAPI definitions

ReviewJobs.Name: Generates documentation through libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


OpenAPI documents allow you to convert the metadata about your API into some other readable format. The OpenAPI specification is a document that describes the capabilities of your API. The document is based on the XML and attribute annotations within the controllers and models. It's the core part of the OpenAPI flow and is used to drive toolings such as SwaggerUI, Doxygen, and NSwag.


Skills


  • Uses Data Annotation attributes to specify contract details in OpenAPI specification.
  • Uses Produce attributes to describe the response types.
  • Uses Produce attributes to describe the response code.


Knowledge


  • What is OpenAPI specification?
  • Which are supported formats? (JSON or YAML)

LearningResources.Name: Implementing Durable Job Chaining in Quartz.NET
Scaling Hangfire: Process More Jobs Concurrently

ReviewJobs.Name: Manages task scheduling and long-running background processing with libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


Task scheduling is the process of executing tasks in a planned manner based on such factors like priority and dependencies. Long-running background processing involves executing time-consuming tasks asynchronously while the main application continues its operation. Task scheduling and long-running background processing work together to effectively manage and execute tasks without blocking the main execution thread. This approach ensures a responsive user interface and the continuous operation of critical components in an application.


Skills


Hangfire

  • Configures infrastructure.
  • Creates a background or recurring job.
  • Handles job continuations.
  • Uses job filters.
  • Configures and customizes Dashboard UI.


Quartz.NET

  • Creates and schedules a job.
  • Creates a chain of jobs.
  • Uses JobDataMap.
  • Utilizes listeners to perform event-based actions.


Knowledge


Hangfire

  • What is Hangfire job?
  • How to create and execute background job?
  • What is JobContext?
  • Where job status, retries, and failed jobs can be tracked?
  • What are the available storage types in Hangfire? What information is stored there?
  • What are Hangfire's mechanisms for handling exceptions and failures?
  • How to process jobs in a separate service?
  • How to scale the execution of jobs?


Quartz.NET

  • How to schedule a job to run at a specific time?
  • Difference between a Job and a Trigger.
  • How to pass data or parameters to a job?
  • What are the different types of triggers available?
  • What is the purpose of listeners?
  • How Quartz.NET supports job persistence and reliability?
  • What is the role of the JobExecutionContext and what information does it provide?
  • How to use a different job store?
  • How clustering works?

ReviewJobs.Name: Manipulates date and time with libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


Date & Time operations are typical routines in everyday software engineering. Working with calendars, dates, and time has many pitfalls and concepts. Manual implementation attempts are typically bound to fail. At the same time, multiple modern software development kits, frameworks, and libraries provide easy-to-use APIs, abstractions, and infrastructure to describe and operate with the concepts like interval, period, duration, date, time, timezone, local date & time, calendar, etc. Moreover, they are frequently providing capabilities to format and parse them.


Skills


  • Uses libraries to work with different sources of date and time data.
  • Performs advanced date-time operations. works with intervals, periods, durations, time zones, and calendars.
  • Formats date-time data with custom and standard formats like ISO 8601.


Knowledge

  • What are the capabilities of working with the date and time offered in the latest .NET versions?
  • What libraries can be used as a replacement of .NET date and time features?
  • Understanding .NET DateTime pitfalls.
  • What features can 3-rd party date-time libraries offer?

ReviewJobs.Name: Reuses and manages dependencies through dependency injection libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


In software engineering, dependency injection is a design pattern in which an object or function receives other objects or functions that it depends on. A form of inversion of control, dependency injection aims to separate the concerns of constructing objects and using them, leading to loosely coupled programs. Typically, specialized libraries and frameworks help engineers to implement dependency injection principles in their software systems.


Skills


.NET dependency injection

  • Uses IServiceProvider for built-in IoC Container in ASP.Net Core.
  • Defines service lifetimes.
  • Uses three different ways to inject and access the registered services in the DI container.


Autofac

1.Uses NuGet package to download Autofac IoC container.

2.At application startup

  • Creates a ContainerBuilder.
  • Registers components.
  • Setups the container and stores it for later use.

3.During application execution

  • Creates a lifetime scope from the container.
  • Uses the lifetime scope to resolve instances of the components.


Unity

  • Defines how to use Unity in your application.
  • Uses NuGet package to download Unity IoC container.
  • Creates instance(s).
  • Defines the Type Mapping.
  • Defines service lifetimes.


Knowledge


.NET dependency injection

  • When to use .NET dependency injection?
  • Understanding multiple constructor discovery rules.
  • Understanding service lifetimes.
  • Understanding  different ways to implement DI.


Autofac

  • What's Autofac? When to use Autofac?
  • Understanding service lifetimes.
  • Understanding different ways to implement DI.
  • Understanding work with the object(s) to be disposed of.


Unity

  • What's Unity? When to use Unity?
  • Understanding service lifetimes.
  • Understanding different ways to implement DI.
  • Specifying Values for Injection.
  • How to resolve arrays and enumerations of types?
  • Understanding strategies to allow deferred resolution of types.

ReviewJobs.Name: Simplifies database management using libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


In computer science, Object-Relational Mapping / Object-Document Mapping (ORM / ODM) is a programming technique used with object-oriented programming languages to transform data across type systems. This creates, in effect, a "virtual object database" that can be used from within the programming language. ORM / ODM frequently requires less coding than conventional methods of communication between an object-oriented language and a relational database. The high degree of abstraction that hides what is actually happening in the implementation code is the main cause of ORM / ODM tool drawbacks.


Skills


Entity Framework Core

  • Uses EF Migrations to manage database schemas.
  • Uses Scaffolding to manage database schemas.
  • Uses data annotations or fluent Api to customize the models.
  • Defines and configures database relations (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many)
  • Manages database transactions


NHibernate

  • Uses NHibernate tools to manage database schemas.
  • Uses mapping by code to customize the models.
  • Defines and configures database relations (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many)
  • Manages database transactions


 Dapper

  • Uses Dapper SplitOn to map a single row to multiple objects.
  • Uses FluentMigrator to manage database schemas.
  • Uses custom mapping or FluentMap extension to customize the models.
  • Manages database transactions


Knowledge


Entity Framework Core

  • Understanding database schema migration
  • Understanding Entity lifecycle
  • Understanding code/model/database first approaches.
  • Understanding tables relationships in database.
  • When to use transactions?
  • Understanding Transaction Isolation Levels


NHibernate

  • Understanding database schema migration
  • Understanding Entity lifecycle
  • Understanding tables relationships in database.
  • When to use transactions?
  • Understanding Transaction Isolation Levels


 Dapper

  • Understanding database schema migration
  • What is Multi Mapping?
  • When to use transactions?
  • Understanding Transaction Isolation Levels

LearningResources.Name: Calling all APIs… How to use Flurl with C#
Executable Tutorial: API Testing using RestSharp And SpecFlow
Use Refit Library to Call Rest Api Endpoint in C# and Asp.net Core
Using Refit to Consume APIs in C#
Using RestSharp To Consume APIs in C#

ReviewJobs.Name: Uses HTTP client libraries for API communication
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


An HTTP client can be incorporated into the project to facilitate communication between a software application and an API over the HTTP protocol. The HTTP client provides a set of tools and functions to manage the exchange of data between the application and the API, simplifying the process of sending and receiving HTTP requests and responses. This approach enables the application to interact with the API in a standardized way, making it more efficient and easier to maintain. Additionally, using an HTTP client allows for more robust error handling, improved performance, and better security.


Skills


Flurl

  • Makes API calls using Flurl functionality.
  • Configures the default behavior of the client.
  • Appropriately handles and logs exceptions.
  • Uses Flurl's built-in mocking capabilities to mock HTTP requests and responses.


Refit

  • Defines an API interface that performs HTTP requests.
  • Specifies request parameters and their serialization.
  • Appropriately handles and logs exceptions.


RestSharp

  • Creates RestRequests with parameters and headers.
  • Handles response with RestSharp's built-in deserialization.
  • Appropriately handles and logs exceptions.



Knowledge


Flurl

  • How do you construct a request?
  • How to add a header to a request?
  • How to deserialize response data?
  • What are some options for handling error responses?
  • How to handle authentication challenges and provide credentials?
  • How to mock HTTP requests and responses for unit testing purposes?
  • How to simulate different scenarios (e.g., successful response, error response) in API tests?



Refit

  • How to define an API interface?
  • How to configure different endpoints within the same API interface?
  • How to deserialize response data?
  • How to integrate authentication mechanisms, such as bearer tokens, with Refit requests?
  • How does Refit handle error responses?
  • How to configure additional settings or handlers for the underlying HttpClient?
  • How to mock Refit API interfaces for unit testing?


RestSharp

  • How to create a RestRequest?
  • How to deserialize response data?
  • What are common types of Authenticators?
  • How to configure RestSharp Error handling behavior?
  • How to mock RestSharp requests and responses for unit testing purposes?

ReviewJobs.Name: Validates data with libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


In an application or system, data validation is meant to offer specific, well-defined guarantees for the fitness and consistency of the data. Different approaches may be used to establish and design data validation rules, which can then be implemented in different contexts. It uses routines, often called "validation rules" and "validation constraints." The automatic capabilities of a data dictionary or the explicit application program validation logic of the computer and its application may be used to apply the rules.


Skills


  • Parses, formats, and validates phone numbers.
  • Validates date and time strings.
  • Validates emails, domains, and IP addresses.
  • Validates currency strings, credit card numbers, IBANs.
  • Performs initial validation for method arguments e.g. - value is not null, not empty, is in range, less than, greater than, etc.) 


Knowledge


  • What are the most common validation types?
  • Pros and cons of using third-party validation libraries?
  • Why is it important to validate user inputs?

ReviewJobs.Name: Uses libraries to implement logging functionality
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description


In software, a log is the automatically created and time-stamped record of events relevant to a particular system. It is crucial for software development and debugging. A lot of logging approaches and implementations exist across a variety of different platforms: from system outputs to files and network-based logs. Together with it, many handy standardized logging libraries and frameworks cover logging needs conveniently, with maintainability and extensibility by design.


Skills

Serilog

  • Initializes Serilog in the startup files.
  • Writes log messages.
  • Uses formatting to create structured logs.
  • Uses appropriate log level.
  • Creates a custom sink that writes log messages to a specific destination.
  • Configures middleware to intercept and log all unhandled exceptions.

Log4Net

  • Initializes Log4Net in the startup files.
  • Writes log messages.
  • Creates a named logger to provide more context and control over the logging output.
  • Uses formatting to create structured logs.
  • Uses appropriate log level.
  • Creates custom log levels.
  • Creates custom appender.
  • Configures middleware to intercept and log all unhandled exceptions.

 NLog

  • Initializes NLog in the startup files.
  • Writes log messages.
  • Uses formatting to create structured logs.
  • Uses appropriate log level.
  • Configures targets, rules and filters.
  • Configures middleware to intercept and log all unhandled exceptions.


Knowledge

Serilog

  • How to configure Serilog?
  • How to write a log message using Serilog?
  • What are some best practices for formatting log messages?
  • What are Serilog logging levels?
  • How to set up sinks in Serilog? Name some commonly used sinks?
  • How to configure Serilog to use multiple sinks simultaneously?
  • How to set up logging filters in Serilog to control which messages get logged?
  • How to log exceptions and stack traces?

Log4Net

  • How to configure Log4Net?
  • How to write a log message using Log4Net?
  • What are some best practices for formatting log messages?
  • What are Log4Net logging levels?
  • How to set up appenders in Log4Net. Name some commonly used appenders.
  • How to configure Log4Net to use multiple appenders simultaneously?
  • What is the difference between rolling and fixed file appenders?
  • How to log exceptions and stack traces?

 NLog

  • How to configure NLog?
  • How to write a log message using NLog?
  • What are some best practices for formatting log messages?
  • What are NLog logging levels?
  • How to set up targets and rules in NLog? Name some commonly used targets?
  • How to configure NLog to use multiple targets simultaneously?
  • What is the difference between buffered and non-buffered logging?
  • How to log exceptions and stack traces?

ReviewJobs.Name: Leads the creation of shared library ecosystems across the organization
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

Shared library ecosystems are essential for promoting code reuse, maintaining consistency, and ensuring efficiency across multiple teams and projects. This task involves designing and managing organization-wide libraries that centralize core functionality, eliminate redundancy, and standardize solutions. It focuses on improving development workflows, ensuring alignment with engineering standards, and fostering collaboration across teams through shared resources.

ReviewJobs.Name: Creates extensible plugin-based systems with libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

Plugin-based systems provide flexibility and scalability by allowing additional functionality to be added without modifying the core system. This task focuses on leveraging libraries to design modular and extensible architectures where plugins can be seamlessly integrated or replaced. Such systems are critical for maintaining long-term adaptability, reducing complexity, and enabling custom feature development for evolving business needs.

ReviewJobs.Name: Optimizes critical system performance using profiling and benchmarking libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

System performance is a critical factor in ensuring responsiveness, scalability, and resource efficiency. This task involves using profiling and benchmarking libraries to analyze system behavior, identify bottlenecks, and measure execution times. By applying these tools, performance-critical sections are optimized, ensuring faster response times, reduced resource usage, and an improved user experience in production environments.

ReviewJobs.Name: Integrates libraries for automated observability and monitoring
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

Observability and monitoring are essential for maintaining system reliability and identifying issues before they impact users. This task involves integrating libraries that enable automated logging, tracing, and metrics collection. Such libraries help engineers monitor system health, analyze failures, and ensure visibility into real-time operations, leading to faster issue resolution and improved system uptime.

ReviewJobs.Name: Introduces transformative libraries to enable technical innovation
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

Staying ahead in the competitive technology landscape requires continuous innovation. This task focuses on researching, evaluating, and introducing new libraries that transform the way solutions are built. By validating and advocating for innovative tools, teams can adopt modern approaches, improve development speed, and deliver cutting-edge solutions aligned with current and future business goals.

ReviewJobs.Name: Designs and develops enterprise-grade custom libraries
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

In enterprise-scale applications, the need for custom libraries arises to solve unique challenges and standardize core functionality. This task involves designing and developing reusable, high-performance libraries tailored to specific organizational needs. These libraries improve maintainability, reduce code duplication, and streamline integration across multiple projects while adhering to engineering best practices.

ReviewJobs.Name: Optimizes application architecture using library approaches, patterns and instrumentary
ReviewJobs.Description:
Job Description

Application architecture plays a critical role in ensuring scalability, maintainability, and resilience. This task involves leveraging advanced libraries and patterns to optimize system architecture, addressing complex challenges such as high-load performance, distributed system design, and fault tolerance. The focus is on achieving long-term architectural goals while ensuring alignment with business and technical requirements.
